abstract.p: In this article, we propose a bifurcation control method for a parametrically excited cantilever beam by linear feedback. Quadratic damping plays a dominant role in the nonlinear response of the parametrically excited cantilever beam, and two transcritical bifurcations can exist in the frequency–response curve. In the relatively high-amplitude excitation or in sweeping the excitation amplitude, there are two saddle-node bifurcations in addition to the transcritical bifurcations. The discontinuous bifurcation as a saddle-node bifurcation induces jumping phenomena in the sweeps of the excitation amplitude and the excitation frequency. In this article, we focus on the case of the excitation amplitude sweep and propose a control method to avoid the jumping phenomena by bifurcation control, i.e. by shifting the bifurcation set based on the linear feedback. The validity of the control method is experimentally confirmed using a simple apparatus.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Parametric resonance in beams has been investigated by a number of researchers because the steady-state response is essentially governed by the nonlinearities in the systems due to various effects such as the geometrical or material nonlinear stiffness and longitudinal motion of a mass at one end of the beam.1–6 In contrast to the parametrically excited beam with fixed or hinged ends which has no free end, the nonlinear dynamics of the beam with a free end as a cantilever beam is affected by quadratic damping.7 For the case in which there is no free end, the steady-state response amplitudes under the resonance condition are bifurcated from the trivial steady-state through pitchfork bifurcations. On the other hand, in the case of a cantilever with a free end, the steady-state response amplitudes are bifurcated through transcritical bifurcations due to the quadratic damping effect. In addition, saddle-node bifurcations can appear in the frequency–response curve, depending on the tip mass.8

During the past two decades, various types of stabilization control methods have been proposed for the nonlinear dynamics of parametric resonance in beams. Pendulum-type vibration absorbers are often used as a passive controller based on nonlinear coupling with the main system9,10 or on Coulomb friction.11 A sliding mass can also suppress the parametric resonance.12 Although these passive control methods do not need an actuator or sensor, in order to effectively change the nonlinear characteristics of the system and stabilize the parametric resonance, active feedback control methods are required because such methods can flexibly actuate the bifurcation set, which characterizes the nonlinear dynamics of the parametric resonance. A comprehensive review of active control is presented in Chen et al.13 and Yaman and Sen.14 Pioneering research on the active control has been performed by the research group of Nayfeh. Oueini and Nayfeh15 applied an active autoparametric vibration absorber that works by nonlinear coupling between the main system and the absorber. The absorber is not a mechanical system and is virtually constructed in a digital computer by simulating the absorber dynamics.16 Oueini and Nayfeh17 first proposed an active controller for parametric resonance using cubic velocity feedback. This control method can directly change the averaged equation, which determines the nonlinear dynamics of the parametric resonance and can be more flexible and versatile than a control method using additional absorbers. The same method is also applied to the vibration control of a system subjected to parametric and external excitations.18 Yamann and Sen14 applied the cubic velocity feedback control method to the vibration control of a parametrically excited cantilever beam of varying orientations. The cubic velocity feedback for the parametric resonance is investigated from the viewpoint of bifurcation control.19–21 Bifurcation control of the parametric resonance is regarded as a relatively complicated control for the system generating a codimension-2 bifurcation. Chen et al.13 and Yaman and Sen14 introduced a special parameter to simplify the bifurcation control method proposed in Yabuno.21 Furthermore, the effect of time delays of the practical controller on nonlinear feedback control for the parametrically excited cantilever22 and a positive utilization of the time delay for the control of horseshoes chaos in a buckled23 have recently been proposed.

Reflecting the fact that the amplitude response of the parametric resonance has nonlinear characteristics, as found in almost all previous research, the control inputs have been generally established by nonlinear feedback. In this article, we propose a bifurcation control based on linear feedback control, which shifts the bifurcation set to eliminate the discontinuous saddle-node bifurcations. Using the method of multiple scales, we derive the amplitude equation used to describe the steady-state amplitude under linear position feedback. How the bifurcation sets for the transcritical and saddle-node bifurcations are shifted by the linear position feedback is clarified. The linear feedback gain is theoretically determined in order to eliminate the saddle-node bifurcations while sweeping the excitation amplitude. Furthermore, the validity of the proposed feedback control method is experimentally confirmed using a simple apparatus of a parametrically excited cantilever.

sec.title: Frequency–response curve and bifurcation set
sec.p:
From equation (34), we show the frequency–response curves for ε = 5.46 × 10−3, 5.88 × 10−3, and 6.30 × 10−3 in Figure 2, corresponding to the subsequent experiment. The experimental results denoted by the ○ symbol are described later herein. In the relatively large excitation amplitude, the saddle-node bifurcations at the points are denoted by the □ symbol in Figure 2; the saddle-node bifurcation in the averaged system corresponds to cyclic fold bifurcations in the full system. The bifurcation sets are described as shown in Figure 3 (the expansion is Figure 4). The vertical two-dot chain lines of ε = 5.46 × 10−3 and ε = 6.30 × 10−3 correspond to the frequency–response curves of Figure 2(a) and (b), respectively. The two-dot chain line of ε = 5.46 × 10−3 in the relatively small excitation amplitude crosses only the solid line, denoting the bifurcation set of the transcritical bifurcation, and the system undergoes transcritical bifurcations, but the saddle-node bifurcations are not produced. On the other hand, the vertical two-dot chain line of ε = 6.30 × 10−3 in the relatively large excitation amplitude crosses not only the solid line expressing the bifurcation set of the transcritical bifurcation, but also the dashed lines denoting the bifurcation set of the saddle-node bifurcation. Therefore, the system undergoes both transcritical and saddle-node bifurcations while sweeping the excitation frequency. Figure 2.

sec.title: Bifurcation control by linear feedback control
sec.p:
In this section, we propose a bifurcation control to eliminate the jumping phenomena during sweeping. In the case of sweeping, the excitation frequency, application of the linear velocity feedback is effective because this shifts the bifurcation sets in Figure 3 to the right direction, so that the vertical two-dot chain line representing the sweep of the excitation frequency does not cross the bifurcation sets for the transcritical and saddle-node bifurcations as mentioned in a previous study.21 On the other hand, in the case of sweeping, the excitation amplitude denoted by the horizontal dash–dotted line, the system undergoes transcritical or saddle-node bifurcation because the dash–dotted line must cross their bifurcation sets. Hence, in the sweep along the horizontal dash–dotted line of σ = σ1 in Figure 6, the system undergoes the transcritical bifurcation, and in the sweep along the horizontal dash–dotted line of σ = σ2 < 0, in addition to transcritical bifurcation, the system undergoes the saddle-node bifurcation. Due to the saddle-node bifurcation which is discontinuous, the system experiences the jumping phenomenon. Figure 6.
Bifurcation set. (a) Case without control. In the sweep of the excitation amplitude along the line σ = σ1, the system overcomes only transcritical bifurcation. In the sweep of the excitation amplitude along the line σ = σ2, in addition to the transcritical bifurcation, the system undergoes the saddle-node bifurcations. (b) Case with linear feedback control. The system does not undergoes saddle-node bifurcations even in the case of σ = σ2. —— and – – – indicate the theoretically obtained transcritical and saddle-node bifurcation sets, respectively.

sec.title: Experimental apparatus
sec.p:
The experimental apparatus is shown in Figure 8. The support point of the cantilever beam with a piezo actuator for the control is excited in the axial direction using a linear bearing (THK Corp., Kr33) connected to a servo-motor (Yasukawa Corp. sec.title: Frequency–response curve and bifurcation set for the case without control
sec.p: The experimentally obtained frequency–response curves are indicated by ○ symbols in Figure 2. In contrast to the experimental results, the theoretical response curve in the case of relatively small excitation (ε = 5.46 × 10−3 : ab = 2.6 mm) does not exhibit the saddle-node bifurcation and instead has only transcritical bifurcations. Except for this discrepancy, the experimental frequency–response curves are qualitatively in good agreement with the theoretical frequency–response curves. The magnitude of the quadratic damping term determines if there are saddle-node bifurcations or not as clarified in Yabuno et al.8 The location of the saddle-node bifurcation set, denoted as dashed line in Figure 3, is affected by the quadratic damping and there is no saddle-node bifurcation in the region of small excitation amplitude ε. The case of Figure 2(a) (ε = 5.46) is near the smallest excitation amplitude in which there are saddle-node bifurcations. We think that the difficulty of the estimation of quadratic damping effect on the cantilever causes the discrepancy.

In Figure 3, the experimentally obtained steady states are plotted. Here, × denotes the excitation condition in which only the zero-amplitude response exists, ▵ the excitation condition in which the response amplitude varies with time and there is no steady-state amplitude, ○ the excitation condition in which only nontrivial steady state exists, and • the excitation condition in which both the trivial and nontrivial steady states exist. The region that includes • corresponds to the region between the sets of saddle-node bifurcations and hysteresis in the force-response curve appears in this region, as shown in Figure 5.

Next, we show the experimentally obtained force-response curve of N/(2π) = 7.203 Hz in Figure 10 which corresponds to the force response along σ = −0.07 in Figure 3. In contrast to the theoretical force-response curve of Figure 5, the nontrivial stable short branch bifurcated from the transcritical bifurcation point cannot be observed around ab = 2.3 mm, but the hysteresis is experimentally confirmed due to the saddle-node bifurcation denoted by the □ symbols. The time histories for the nontrivial steady-state responses observed in ab = 2.2 mm, and the excitation of the support point are shown in Figure 11, and their corresponding frequency components are shown in Figure 12. The experimentally obtained force–response curve of N/(2π) = 7.203 Hz is shown in Figure 13. This figure corresponds to the force response along σ = 0.07 in Figure 3. In this excitation condition, there is no saddle-node bifurcation and the force–response curve is continuous as theoretically predicted. In the following section, we apply the linear feedback control in order to eliminate the saddle-node bifurcation in Figure 10. Figure 12.

sec.title: Bifurcation control under linear feedback
sec.p:
Figure 14 shows the force response under the linear feedback control proposed theoretically in `Bifurcation control by linear feedback control' section. The excitation condition is the same as that in Figure 10 and the linear feedback gain is (k1 = 3970 V/m). Under the feedback control, the bifurcation set is shifted, as shown in Figure 6 and the continuous bifurcation, as shown in Figure 14, is performed and the saddle-node bifurcation is eliminated. Figure 13.
Steady-state response of the beam for the case without control. The excitation frequency is constant at N/2π = 7.283 Hz corresponding to σ = 0.07. The ⋄ symbol indicates the transcritical bifurcation points.

Figure 15 shows the time history in the steady state under the linear feedback control in which (a), (b), and (c) are the excitations of the support point of the beam, the response of the beam, and the bending moment applied by the piezo actuator according to the linear feedback control, respectively. Figure 16 shows the frequency analysis for each time history. Under the linear feedback, the piezo actuator applies the bending moment with the same frequency as the response of the parametrically excited beam which is equivalent to half the excitation frequency. Figure 14.
Steady-state response of the beam with control with a feedback gain of K1 = 3000 V/m. The ⋄ symbol indicates the transcritical bifurcation points. Figure 15.

The most advantage of the proposed control method is to avoid the jumping phenomena by eliminating the discontinuous bifurcations. Even if the control is applied to the case of other excitation frequency in the resonance region, not including discontinuous bifurcations, because the cross point between the solid and dashed–dotted lines is shifted to the larger excitation amplitude, it is possible to decrease the response amplitude due to the delay of the transcritical bifurcation under the proposed control method.

sec.title: Force response in the sweep of the excitation amplitude
sec.p:
We apply the sweep of the excitation amplitude as follows (44) where ab 'mm is the excitation amplitude at the start of the sweep and c′ mm/s the sweep ratio. Figure 17 shows the experimentally obtained time history of the force response under the sweep in which (a), (c), and (e) are the time histories for the beam, the bending moment applied by the piezo actuator, and the excitation of the support point, respectively, for the case without control and (b), (d), and (f) are the time histories for the beam, the bending moment applied by the piezo actuator, and the excitation of the support point, respectively, for the case with control. Here, the shaded areas in (a) and (b) indicate the positive portion of the experimentally obtained time history of the force response. In addition, for reference, the steady-state amplitudes are indicated by the ○ symbols in (a) and (b). For the case without control, due to the discontinuous bifurcation, a jumping phenomenon occurs. On the other hand, under the feedback control, the steady-state amplitude is continuous as indicated by the ○ symbols in (b). However, in the sweep, a state without amplitude exists even beyond the bifurcation point (ab ≈ 1.95 mm). Due to this penetration phenomenon,26 jumping phenomena are generated, but are sufficiently small. Figure 16.

(b), (d), and (f) are the time histories of the cantilever, the bending moment applied to the cantilever, and the excitation of the support point of the cantilever, respectively, for the case with control. The sweep ratio is c′ = 0.001 mm/s; (a) and (b) show the positive portion of the time history and the experimentally obtained steady-state amplitudes are indicated by ○ symbols.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, in order to eliminate discontinuous bifurcation due to the saddle-node bifurcation, we propose a bifurcation control method that is achieved by linear position feedback. Under the proposed control, the bifurcation set of the saddle-node bifurcation is shifted such that the system does not undergo the saddle-node bifurcation in the sweep of the excitation amplitude. Using a simple apparatus, the validity of the theoretically proposed control method is experimentally confirmed through the results of the frequency–response curve and the transient response in the sweep of the excitation amplitude.
